Sounds to me you need to disable "battery optimization" for k9.

Just saying, but sometimes you have to move beyond your roots. Even Dr. Who updated k9. Still, I'd venture that Dr who means nothing to most users of k9 mail. I've never watched Dr. Who. Don't care. I use to mail because it's powerful and it's open source.

We experience this often because, in order to save battery, wifi shuts off when device sleeps. Therefore, upon waking, the device has to re-connect to wifi...thus triggering this issue.

See also: misfeatures, feature creep, bloat. We'll always be totally configurable in the Apache 2.0 sense though :)

The reason it might poll a minute late is because we don't ask for exact 'alarms' from Android because we take the view that it's not worth the battery trade-off. So Android can  and often does trigger the event slightly early or slightly late to match a device wake-up window.

In k9mail you can set pop3 account to be checked every 1 or 5 or 10 or 15 ... minutes. That is very large increase. Between 1 min -> 5 minutes is 500% increase. I would like to set it to 2 or 3 minutes since 5 is too much and 1 drains battery and increases network usage too much. There is no option to do this. Please implement option to type in any interval in minutes.

In general we don't store every e-mail either - a mobile client making server-side searches to work out if stuff needs archiving seems crazy to me.

This will make Newpipe way more flexible and powerful. A lot of people like to download the audio from LONG videos and then listen to it using an audio player so we don't have to stream it again and not lose our place. Adding all the bitrates that are possible will allow us to get low quality audio for basic spoken word stuff and high quality audio for music stuff.

Even a slower phone will do 3 threads just fine. No need to go below 3 unless you have an ancient phone and even that should just have 2 threads. The SOCs on phones, even 5 year old phones are powerful enough to do multi-threaded data transfer with no slowdown at all.

This is because the popup player now stops the video renderer when you turn off your screen. No video decoding when the screen is off == uses less battery usage when playing in the background.  Of course, this comes at the cost of needing to seek once the screen is active again. We can revert this feature if it becomes too annoying.

Yesterday when I updated to the latest version I was thrilled to see that subscriptions had been added as a feature: it's killer! :) I personally use NewPipe mainly to download videos for offline viewing. Because I spend a lot of time outdoors where I've had limited amounts of power available to me, I try to minimize activities such as streaming content or using the internet in the woods as much as possible to conserve power. Therefore, once I visit civilization, I download many days' worth of content at a time that I can then watch offline when in the woods.

First of all, it isn't our decision what people do on their phones. The only waste of resources with pointless conversions could be electric energy and CPU cycles. But it would even save resources on the flash storage of a phone, considering that a file encoded with a lower bitrate (or a more modern encoder) will consume less space. So that argument isn't valid.

Thank you for acknowledging my issues.I think new host editor screen shows up when pressing Add button on the hosts screen, or when long pressing a host in the list and choosing edit in its popup menu. As far as I think this screen is fully accessible.I don't know if Connectbot can remember ssh password, I would expect a corresponding password entry in this dialog. At the other hand I understand it does not perhaps remember passwords entered via keyboard because of the possible security concerns.As for the consistency you appear to have changed all switches on this screen to so called checkable menu item views however when enabling "Use ssh agent" option, there is a checkbox saying "require confirmation". This is plain checkbox. It's still accessible though.When not considering accessibility at all terminal is a control where we can see output from a console. It does not provide ability to navigate over the text using the keyboard because almost all the input is passed throught to the application running inside a terminal. It is possible to scroll the terminal by using the mouse and there might be a terminal implementation specific mode allowing caret navigation over the text (screen comes to my mind while writting this).Thus on other platforms (e.g. command prompt on Windows, Gnome terminal on linux desktop, or even pure virtual console on unix / linux like systems) ability to review the content of a terminal is left to the screen readers. Screen readers on all these platforms including android alter the interaction paradigm a bit (on android it's through so called explore by touch mode where touching does not activate views under the finger but double tap is needed).So according to this we should override as little when it comes to the interaction and navigation as possible. Of course that may lead to some compromises but that is really the way to go I think because ideally this should just work and people should discover working platform native accessibility support from the start since they have launched the app.Trying to further explain on this consider just any view on android be it a label next to an interactive view such as text entry, checkbox or just a simple text view displaying text inside a dialog. Such a control also does not provide its specific navigation commands. People who don't need screen readers / assistive technologies will just look at it and those relying on the accessibility support will receive platform / disability specific support. So our terminal view should work as close as possible to this. This is perhaps partially opposite you might have gathered from Casey Burkhartd a few years ago while meging his original accessibility related patches but I think this might be because accessibility was not there on Android since its day one and at that time I think it had still been evolving.Unfortunatelly there is one big challenge on Android. When using screen readers on other platforms with interactive apps running inside a terminal that manipulate the caret such as text editors, file manager and similar, screen readers on the platforms where there is not enough API for such interaction are monitoring caret position and try to report new context as it changes. On the platforms where there are APIS for this the terminal view sends an event describing caret movement and screen readers can then just report the event. I think there is such an API on Android however I imagine it might be tricky to implement so I would make this second most priority after basic text changes and text review is working.Now to your questions:* Frankly Most blind people have natural issues handling colours, color changes and similar. I wo-ld say for typical console based apps such as built-in shell, core utils and similar apps it's not important at all. I know people tend to format their ls output with coours for example but I am never doing that and I think other blind people might have similar habits. In interactive apps such as ncurses based ones, colours might indicate a particular control an author would like to resemble. So if we might be able to get that far then on Windows and on Linux (GTK and QT) there are accessibility API's where authors can describe text formatting. Hopefully there is something similar on Android. The only apps I have recognized providing such text formatting details to screen readers are Google docs and spreadsheets. I am not sure this is documented. I suggest to put this aside until all more serious accessibility issues are ,addressed.* Screen clear perhaps means that terminal content is cleared in order to be replaced with new content as it arrives. I imagine looking at a ls command output and then deciding to open one of the files in nano for example. listing is cleared and new content is displayed as the new application generates content. I expect this to also happen with so called accessibility buffer.* There is no magic related to box draving characters. These might just be any characters such as a bunch of dashes, bunch of letter I and similar. Terminal emulators on other platforms don't filter out these.* When touch exploration is in effect there are various approaches and I am not sure we are going to override the default behaviour reporting all the text of a view. When explore by touch is activated on android handling touch events works differently than while explore by touch is off. If there will be enough energy and knowledge perhaps reporting individual lines or word as they are touched is doable. Touching individual characters seem overly verbosed and highly inefficient to me. I think this needs further research.* I've already written some thoughts on caret handling above when trying to explain the whole situation. This needs further research. I hope there's an API allowing us to fire caret moved events or something to that effect.* Repeating what has been read, spelling out, applying phonetic spelling such as alpha, bravo, charlie, delta.... this is the screen reader business and I hope you shouldn't need to tackle this.Excuse me for such a huge post. I've tried to write everything I know so you can take the best out of it.I am sure this will take a lot of time from both of us and perhaps some others if they will be able to join us in this.As I've said for the whole community this might become a life changer so while I'm excited I think even croud funding might be possible.thanks once again

Personally I use the font [Hack](https://github.com/chrissimpkins/Hack) because it's a great monospaced font. What makes this a necessity though is that I'm a heavy user of Vim/Neovim and that plugins like air-/powerline demand a few special glyphs to be patched into the font. [Hack](https://github.com/chrissimpkins/Hack) for example already has those glyphs patched which are essential for proper rendering of some advanced features.

Tasker's plugin API is based on Locale's plugin API. Locale came first, but Tasker was a lot more powerful, and got more traction. If you write a Locale-compatible plugin, it will automatically work with Tasker.

@Kronzky AdGuard has various advanced options that turn on filtering of only DNS requests, compare https://blog.adguard.com/en/great-battery-saving-mode-of-adguard-for-android/ - by default it trades battery life for a better ad blocking experience.

1. DNS66 only redirects DNS traffic, nothing else. An upstream proxy would require redirecting all traffic, and that has one problem: All that traffic will be accounted to DNS66, making it look quite bad in battery stats.

Can we have something like when the device is idle, turn the VPN off to save more charge/power/battery/whatever? Then when you wake it up, the VPN gets automatically turned on (i meant VPN is enabled). I am sure this is possible. Is it too much for an open source or a free app? 😆

When screen is off, Doze prevents  apps from sending or receiving data without disabling  Wi-Fi or 2G/3G/4G data. In this way it adds more hours to standby time and makes significant difference to battery life.

Also forgot to mention in the review. We are missing a sensible icon for the quick toggle (a power logo does not seem that useful for a quick toggle). That can be solved with #10, or in here as a modification of the launcher icon, although that does not seem to lend itself to such modifications.

Cosmetic filtering of pages likely requires us to modify the pages - which we increasingly cannot do, as they are HTTPS. Even without HTTPS, if we want to modify pages, we'd have to redirect all traffic through the VPN, causing battery drain (or at least skewed stats).
It does an incredible job and by the nature of its functionality virtually no battery drain etc.  In fact blocking ads will help the device load pages/apps faster, etc.
Maybe it's a power optimization that is killing the app.
This needs to be limited though - like maybe show the last 128 requests or so. And it needs to be as efficient as possible - both in space and power consumption.
Then we end up with a more privacy focused (ad-free) version of NetGuard. It's a nice idea, but it eats a lot more battery: The entire network traffic needs to be routed via the VPN.

No sorry, that's out of scope. We're filtering at a completely different, far lower level. DNS66 never sees your http traffic, so it can't redirect it to https. It's theoretically possible to do this though, but that would have a really big impact on performance and battery life.
